column10: Postorder traversal gives postfix expression.

column4: What is the time complexity of linear search?
column6: O(log n)
column10: Linear search scans all elements, O(n).

column4: Which algorithm is best for finding all pairs shortest path?
column5: Dijkstra
column6: Floyd-Warshall
column10: Floyd-Warshall finds APSP.

column4: What is the maximum number of edges in a simple undirected graph with n vertices?
column10: Maximum edges = n(n-1)/2.

column4: Which sorting algorithm is best when the input is nearly sorted?
column5: Quick Sort
column6: Insertion Sort
column10: Insertion Sort works efficiently on nearly sorted arrays.

column4: Which data structure is commonly used for implementing undo functionality?
column5: Queue
column6: Stack
column10: Undo uses stack to reverse actions.

column4: Which algorithm is used in Huffman coding?
column5: Greedy
column6: Dynamic Programming
column10: Huffman coding is a greedy algorithm.

column4: What is the time complexity of enqueue operation in a circular queue?
column6: O(log n)
column10: Enqueue in circular queue takes O(1).

column4: Which algorithm is used for maximum flow problem?
column5: Prim
column6: Kruskal
column10: Ford-Fulkerson solves max flow problem.

column4: What is the time complexity of inserting into a B-Tree of order m?
column6: O(log n)
column10: Insertions in B-Tree take O(log n).

column4: Which algorithm is used for searching in a sorted array?
column5: Binary Search
column6: Linear Search
column10: Binary Search is efficient on sorted arrays.

column4: What is the time complexity of finding the height of a binary tree?
column6: O(n)
column10: A DFS traversal visits each node once, O(n).

column4: Which algorithm is used for finding articulation points in a graph?
column5: DFS
column6: BFS
column10: DFS is used for finding articulation points.

column4: Which data structure is used to check for balanced parentheses?
column5: Queue
column6: Stack
column10: Stack is used for parentheses checking.

column4: Which algorithm uses dynamic programming to solve shortest path?
column5: Dijkstra
column6: Bellman-Ford
column10: Floyd-Warshall uses DP.performance_id

column4: What is the primary goal of supervised learning?
column5: To cluster similar data points
column6: To predict a target variable from labeled data
column7: To reduce the dimensionality of data
column8: To find hidden patterns in data
column10: Supervised learning uses a training dataset with labeled output to learn a mapping from inputs to the output. The goal is to predict the target variable for new, unseen data.

column4: What is a "feature" in a machine learning model?
column5: A type of algorithm
column6: An output or target variable
column7: A column in a dataset used for prediction
column10: In machine learning, a feature is an input variable that is used by the model to make predictions. It is a key piece of information in the dataset.

column4: What is overfitting?
column5: When a model is too simple to capture the underlying trend
column6: When a model performs well on the training data but poorly on unseen data
column7: When a model has a perfect score on all data
column8: When a model is too complex and slow to train
column10: Overfitting occurs when a model learns the training data and noise too well, making it perform poorly on new, unseen data. It essentially memorizes the training data instead of learning the general trend.

column4: What is a common task in unsupervised learning?
column5: Classification
column6: Regression
column10: Clustering is a classic example of an unsupervised learning task. It involves grouping similar data points together based on their features without any predefined labels.

column4: Which of these is a popular machine learning library in Python?
column5: NumPy
column6: matplotlib
column10: scikit-learn is a widely-used Python library for machine learning. It provides a vast collection of algorithms for classification, regression, clustering, and more.

column4: What is the difference between classification and regression?
column5: Classification predicts a continuous value; Regression predicts a discrete label
column6: Classification predicts a discrete label; Regression predicts a continuous value
column10: Classification models predict a discrete or categorical outcome (e.g., Spam" or "Not Spam"). Regression models predict a continuous or numerical outcome (e.g.

column4: What is a "confusion matrix" used for?
column5: To visualize model performance on unseen data
column6: To plot the training and validation loss
column7: To evaluate the performance of a classification model
column10: A confusion matrix is a table used to evaluate the performance of a classification model. It shows the number of correct and incorrect predictions for each class, including true positives, false positives, true negatives, and false negatives.

column4: What is the purpose of a validation set?
column5: To train the model on a different set of data
column6: To test the model's final performance before deployment
column7: To tune the model's hyperparameters and prevent overfitting
column10: A validation set is a portion of the training data used to tune hyperparameters and evaluate the model's performance during training, helping to prevent overfitting to the training set.

column4: What is a "hyperparameter" in machine learning?
column5: A parameter learned by the model during training
column6: An external parameter set before training starts
column10: Hyperparameters are external configuration settings for a machine learning algorithm. They are set manually before the training process begins (e.g., learning rate, number of trees in a random forest).

column4: What is the purpose of a "bias-variance tradeoff"?
column5: To find the optimal balance between model complexity and performance
column6: To prevent a model from being biased towards one class
column7: To reduce the computational cost of training
column8: To balance the training and testing data
column10: The bias-variance tradeoff describes the conflict in trying to create a model that is both simple enough to avoid overfitting (low variance) but complex enough to capture the underlying pattern (low bias). Finding the right balance is a key challenge in machine learning.

column4: What is the purpose of a kernel trick in Support Vector Machines (SVM)?
column5: To speed up the training process
column6: To find a linear decision boundary in a high-dimensional space without explicitly computing the coordinates
column7: To reduce the number of features in a dataset
column8: To handle missing values in the data
column10: The kernel trick allows an SVM to implicitly map data into a higher-dimensional feature space, enabling the algorithm to find a linear decision boundary that separates the data, even if the data is not linearly separable in the original space.

column4: Explain the difference between a bagging and boosting ensemble method.
column5: Bagging trains models sequentially; Boosting trains them in parallel
column6: Bagging reduces variance; Boosting reduces bias
column7: Bagging focuses on reducing bias; Boosting focuses on reducing variance
column8: They are different names for the same thing
column10: Bagging (like Random Forest) trains multiple models in parallel and averages their predictions to reduce variance. Boosting (like Gradient Boosting) trains models sequentially, where each new model corrects the errors of the previous one, primarily reducing bias.

column4: What is a Generative Adversarial Network (GAN)?
column5: A neural network used for regression tasks
column6: A network that combines a generative model and a discriminative model
column7: A network used for image classification
column8: A type of recurrent neural network
column10: A GAN consists of two neural networks: a generator that creates new data (e.g., images) and a discriminator that evaluates the data. They are trained in a zero-sum game, where the generator tries to fool the discriminator, and the discriminator tries to correctly identify fake data.

column4: What is the purpose of a "softmax" activation function in the output layer of a neural network?
column5: To add a non-linearity to the model
column6: To convert the outputs into probabilities that sum to 1
column7: To scale the outputs to be between -1 and 1
column8: To reduce the dimensionality of the output
column10: The softmax function is used in multi-class classification problems. It takes a vector of real numbers and normalizes them into a probability distribution, where each value is between 0 and 1 and all values sum to 1.

column4: What is a phishing attack?
column5: An attack that encrypts a user's files and demands a ransom
column6: An attack that uses malware to steal data
column7: An attack that tricks users into revealing personal information
column8: An attack that overloads a network with traffic
column10: A phishing attack is a type of social engineering where an attacker sends a fraudulent message to trick a person into revealing sensitive information, like passwords or credit card numbers.

column4: What is the purpose of a firewall?
column5: To block all internet traffic to a network
column6: To monitor and control incoming and outgoing network traffic
column8: To protect against physical theft of a computer
column10: A firewall is a network security system that monitors and controls network traffic based on a set of security rules. It acts as a barrier between a trusted internal network and untrusted external networks.

column4: What does the acronym DDoS stand for?
column5: Data Destruction on Demand System
column6: Direct Denial of Service
column10: DDoS stands for Distributed Denial of Service. It's an attack where multiple compromised computer systems flood a target's network with traffic to make the service unavailable to legitimate users.

column4: What is a "zero-day" vulnerability?
column5: A vulnerability that has been known for years
column6: A vulnerability that has a severity score of zero
column7: A newly discovered vulnerability that hackers can exploit before a patch is available
column8: A vulnerability that can only be exploited on the first day of the month
column10: A zero-day vulnerability is a software flaw that is not yet known to the vendor or the public. It can be exploited by hackers on the 'zero day' of its public discovery, before a fix is available.

column4: What is the purpose of multi-factor authentication (MFA)?
column5: To make passwords longer
column6: To protect against brute-force attacks
column7: To require more than one method of verification to grant access
column8: To automatically change a user's password
column10: MFA is a security system that requires a user to provide two or more different verification factors to gain access to a resource. It adds an extra layer of security beyond just a password.

column4: What is a SQL Injection attack?
column5: An attack that targets a database with a series of SQL queries
column6: An attack that uses malware to gain unauthorized access to a network
column7: An attack that uses malicious SQL statements to control a database server
column8: An attack that floods a database with too much traffic
column10: A SQL injection attack is a technique that uses malicious SQL statements inserted into a data input field to trick the database into executing unauthorized commands, which can lead to data theft or destruction.

column4: What is the purpose of a VPN (Virtual Private Network)?
column5: To increase network speed
column6: To allow a remote user to securely access a private network over the internet
column10: A VPN creates a secure, encrypted connection over a public network. It allows a user to send and receive data as if they were directly connected to the private network, ensuring confidentiality and security.

column4: What is a "brute-force" attack?
column5: An attack that uses a user's personal information to guess a password
column6: An attack that repeatedly tries different passwords or keys until it finds the correct one
column7: An attack that tricks a user into downloading malware
column8: An attack that targets a specific application
column10: A brute-force attack is a trial-and-error method used to guess a password or login information. The attacker systematically tries all possible combinations of characters until the correct one is found.

column4: What is the purpose of a digital certificate in network security?
column5: To encrypt network traffic
column6: To verify the identity of a website or server
column7: To store a user's password securely
column10: A digital certificate, issued by a Certificate Authority, is used to verify the identity of a website or server. It establishes a secure connection and confirms that the server is who it claims to be.

column4: What is a "Man-in-the-Middle" (MitM) attack?
column5: An attack where a hacker gains unauthorized access to a computer
column6: An attack where an attacker secretly relays and possibly alters the communication between two parties
column7: An attack that uses a trojan to steal data
column8: An attack that targets a specific piece of software
column10: In a MitM attack, an attacker places themselves between two communicating parties and intercepts their messages. The attacker can then read, modify, or inject false information into the communication without either party knowing.

column4: What is the difference between a virus and a worm?
column5: A virus self-replicates; a worm does not
column6: A virus needs a host program to spread; a worm can spread on its own
column7: A virus is a type of worm
column10: A computer virus requires a host program (like a `.exe` file) to run and spread. A worm is a standalone malicious program that can self-replicate and spread to other computers on a network without needing a host program or human action.

column4: What is "cryptographic salt"?
column5: A type of encryption algorithm
column6: Random data used as an additional input to a one-way function that hashes a password
column7: A key used to decrypt data
column8: A type of attack on a cryptosystem
column10: Cryptographic salt is a piece of random data used to modify a password hash. It is added to the password before hashing to prevent a common attack called a rainbow table" attack and makes it harder to crack passwords with pre-computed tables."

column4: What is the purpose of a "Honeypot" in cybersecurity?
column5: A tool used to defend against malware
column6: A server or system designed to attract and trap hackers
column10: A honeypot is a decoy computer system or network designed to attract hackers and cyber attackers. It's a way to study their techniques, gather intelligence, and divert them away from the real network assets.

column4: What is a "generator expression" in Python?
column5: A function that returns a generator
column6: A list comprehension using round brackets
column7: A special kind of for loop
column8: A function that returns an iterable
column10: A generator expression is a concise way to create an iterator, similar to a list comprehension, but using round brackets `()` instead of square brackets `[]`.

column4: What is the purpose of the `__call__` method?
column5: To make an object callable like a function
column6: To call a superclass method
column7: To define a custom string representation
column8: To perform a deep copy of an object
column10: The `__call__` method allows an instance of a class to be called as a function. This makes objects callable, which can be useful for creating custom function-like objects.

column4: What is the purpose of the `__slots__` attribute in a class?
column5: To prevent the creation of new attributes in an object at runtime
column6: To define the variables of an object
column7: To improve the performance of a class by telling Python not to create a `__dict__` for each instance
column8: To specify the order of attributes in a class
column10: The `__slots__` attribute is a performance optimization used to tell Python not to use a `__dict__` to store instance attributes. This can significantly reduce the memory footprint of objects, especially when creating a large number of them.

column4: How does Python's Garbage Collector primarily work?
column5: Using a reference counting mechanism
column6: Using a mark-and-sweep algorithm
column7: Using a combination of reference counting and a cycle detector
column10: Python primarily uses a reference counting system, but to deal with reference cycles (where objects refer to each other and their reference counts never drop to zero), it also employs a separate garbage collector that finds and collects these cycles.

column4: What is the GIL (Global Interpreter Lock)?
column5: A lock on all threads that ensures only one thread executes Python bytecode at a time
column6: A lock that prevents multiple Python processes from running simultaneously
column7: A lock that is part of every Python object to ensure thread safety
column8: A mechanism to manage Python's memory allocation
column10: The GIL is a mutex that protects access to Python objects, preventing multiple threads from executing Python bytecode at the same time. This means that a single-process Python application cannot fully utilize multiple CPU cores for CPU-bound tasks.

column4: What is the time complexity of searching for an element in a binary search tree in the worst case?
column6: O(n)
column10: In the worst case, a binary search tree can degenerate into a linked list (e.g., if elements are inserted in sorted order), making the search operation linear, with a complexity of O(n).

column4: What is a self-balancing binary search tree?
column5: A tree where no node has more than one child
column6: A tree where the height difference between the left and right subtrees of any node is at most 1
column7: A tree where all leaves are at the same level
column8: A tree that automatically sorts its elements
column10: A self-balancing binary search tree (like AVL or Red-Black trees) is a type of BST that automatically keeps its height as small as possible by performing rotations, ensuring that the height difference of subtrees is maintained to ensure O(log n) search time.

column4: What is the time complexity of deleting a node from a binary search tree in the worst case?
column6: O(log n)

column4: What is the "master theorem" in algorithm analysis used for?
column5: To find the minimum spanning tree of a graph
column6: To solve recurrence relations for divide and conquer algorithms
column7: To analyze the space complexity of an algorithm
column8: To find the time complexity of a recursive algorithm without a recurrence relation
column10: The master theorem provides a cookbook method for solving recurrence relations of the form T(n) = aT(n/b) + f(n), which is common in the analysis of divide and conquer algorithms.

column4: What is the time complexity of finding an element in a balanced AVL tree?
column6: O(n)

column4: What is the Bellman-Ford algorithm used for?
column5: Finding the shortest path in a graph with non-negative edge weights

column4: What is the primary goal of supervised learning?

column4: What is overfitting?

column7: When a model has a perfect score on all data
column8: When a model is too complex and slow to train
column10: Overfitting occurs when a model learns the training data and noise too well, making it perform poorly on new, unseen data. It essentially memorizes the training data instead of learning the general trend.

column4: What is a common task in unsupervised learning?

column4: What is the difference between classification and regression?

column4: What is a "confusion matrix" used for?
column5: To visualize model performance on unseen data
column6: To plot the training and validation loss
column7: To evaluate the performance of a classification model
column10: A confusion matrix is a table used to evaluate the performance of a classification model. It shows the number of correct and incorrect predictions for each class, including true positives, false positives, true negatives, and false negatives.

column4: What is the purpose of a validation set?
column5: To train the model on a different set of data
column6: To test the model's final performance before deployment
column7: To tune the model's hyperparameters and prevent overfitting
column10: A validation set is a portion of the training data used to tune hyperparameters and evaluate the model's performance during training, helping to prevent overfitting to the training set.

column4: What is a "hyperparameter" in machine learning?
column5: A parameter learned by the model during training
column6: An external parameter set before training starts
column10: Hyperparameters are external configuration settings for a machine learning algorithm. They are set manually before the training process begins (e.g., learning rate, number of trees in a random forest).

column4: What is the purpose of a "bias-variance tradeoff"?
column5: To find the optimal balance between model complexity and performance
column6: To prevent a model from being biased towards one class
column7: To reduce the computational cost of training
column8: To balance the training and testing data
column10: The bias-variance tradeoff describes the conflict in trying to create a model that is both simple enough to avoid overfitting (low variance) but complex enough to capture the underlying pattern (low bias). Finding the right balance is a key challenge in machine learning.

column4: What is the purpose of a kernel trick in Support Vector Machines (SVM)?

column6: To find a linear decision boundary in a high-dimensional space without explicitly computing the coordinates
column7: To reduce the number of features in a dataset
column8: To handle missing values in the data

column4: Explain the difference between a bagging and boosting ensemble method.
column5: Bagging trains models sequentially; Boosting trains them in parallel
column6: Bagging reduces variance; Boosting reduces bias
column7: Bagging focuses on reducing bias; Boosting focuses on reducing variance

column10: Bagging (like Random Forest) trains multiple models in parallel and averages their predictions to reduce variance. Boosting (like Gradient Boosting) trains models sequentially, where each new model corrects the errors of the previous one, primarily reducing bias.

column4: What is a Generative Adversarial Network (GAN)?

column7: A network used for image classification
column8: A type of recurrent neural network
column10: A GAN consists of two neural networks: a generator that creates new data (e.g., images) and a discriminator that evaluates the data. They are trained in a zero-sum game, where the generator tries to fool the discriminator, and the discriminator tries to correctly identify fake data.

column4: What is the purpose of a "softmax" activation function in the output layer of a neural network?

column4: What is a phishing attack?
column5: An attack that encrypts a user's files and demands a ransom
column6: An attack that uses malware to steal data
column7: An attack that tricks users into revealing personal information
column8: An attack that overloads a network with traffic
column10: A phishing attack is a type of social engineering where an attacker sends a fraudulent message to trick a person into revealing sensitive information, like passwords or credit card numbers.

column4: What is the purpose of a firewall?
column5: To block all internet traffic to a network
column6: To monitor and control incoming and outgoing network traffic
column8: To protect against physical theft of a computer
column10: A firewall is a network security system that monitors and controls network traffic based on a set of security rules. It acts as a barrier between a trusted internal network and untrusted external networks.

column4: What does the acronym DDoS stand for?
column5: Data Destruction on Demand System
column6: Direct Denial of Service
column10: DDoS stands for Distributed Denial of Service. It's an attack where multiple compromised computer systems flood a target's network with traffic to make the service unavailable to legitimate users.

column4: What is a "zero-day" vulnerability?
column5: A vulnerability that has been known for years
column6: A vulnerability that has a severity score of zero
column7: A newly discovered vulnerability that hackers can exploit before a patch is available
column8: A vulnerability that can only be exploited on the first day of the month
column10: A zero-day vulnerability is a software flaw that is not yet known to the vendor or the public. It can be exploited by hackers on the 'zero day' of its public discovery, before a fix is available.

column4: What is the purpose of multi-factor authentication (MFA)?
column5: To make passwords longer
column6: To protect against brute-force attacks
column7: To require more than one method of verification to grant access
column8: To automatically change a user's password
column10: MFA is a security system that requires a user to provide two or more different verification factors to gain access to a resource. It adds an extra layer of security beyond just a password.

column4: What is a SQL Injection attack?
column5: An attack that targets a database with a series of SQL queries
column6: An attack that uses malware to gain unauthorized access to a network
column7: An attack that uses malicious SQL statements to control a database server
column8: An attack that floods a database with too much traffic
column10: A SQL injection attack is a technique that uses malicious SQL statements inserted into a data input field to trick the database into executing unauthorized commands, which can lead to data theft or destruction.

column4: What is the purpose of a VPN (Virtual Private Network)?
column5: To increase network speed
column6: To allow a remote user to securely access a private network over the internet
column10: A VPN creates a secure, encrypted connection over a public network. It allows a user to send and receive data as if they were directly connected to the private network, ensuring confidentiality and security.

column4: What is a "brute-force" attack?
column5: An attack that uses a user's personal information to guess a password
column6: An attack that repeatedly tries different passwords or keys until it finds the correct one
column7: An attack that tricks a user into downloading malware
column8: An attack that targets a specific application
column10: A brute-force attack is a trial-and-error method used to guess a password or login information. The attacker systematically tries all possible combinations of characters until the correct one is found.

column4: What is the purpose of a digital certificate in network security?
column5: To encrypt network traffic
column6: To verify the identity of a website or server
column7: To store a user's password securely
column10: A digital certificate, issued by a Certificate Authority, is used to verify the identity of a website or server. It establishes a secure connection and confirms that the server is who it claims to be.

column4: What is a "Man-in-the-Middle" (MitM) attack?
column5: An attack where a hacker gains unauthorized access to a computer
column6: An attack where an attacker secretly relays and possibly alters the communication between two parties
column7: An attack that uses a trojan to steal data
column8: An attack that targets a specific piece of software
column10: In a MitM attack, an attacker places themselves between two communicating parties and intercepts their messages. The attacker can then read, modify, or inject false information into the communication without either party knowing.

column4: What is the difference between a virus and a worm?
column5: A virus self-replicates; a worm does not
column6: A virus needs a host program to spread; a worm can spread on its own
column7: A virus is a type of worm
column10: A computer virus requires a host program (like a `.exe` file) to run and spread. A worm is a standalone malicious program that can self-replicate and spread to other computers on a network without needing a host program or human action.

column4: What is "cryptographic salt"?

column8: A type of attack on a cryptosystem
column10: Cryptographic salt is a piece of random data used to modify a password hash. It is added to the password before hashing to prevent a common attack called a rainbow table" attack and makes it harder to crack passwords with pre-computed tables."

column4: What is the purpose of a "Honeypot" in cybersecurity?

column4: How does Python's Garbage Collector primarily work?

column10: Python primarily uses a reference counting system, but to deal with reference cycles (where objects refer to each other and their reference counts never drop to zero), it also employs a separate garbage collector that finds and collects these cycles.

column4: What is the GIL (Global Interpreter Lock)?

column6: A lock that prevents multiple Python processes from running simultaneously
column7: A lock that is part of every Python object to ensure thread safety

column10: The GIL is a mutex that protects access to Python objects, preventing multiple threads from executing Python bytecode at the same time. This means that a single-process Python application cannot fully utilize multiple CPU cores for CPU-bound tasks.

column5: A virus self-replicates; a worm does not

column7: A virus is a type of worm
column10: A computer virus requires a host program (like a `.exe` file) to run and spread. A worm is a standalone malicious program that can self-replicate and spread to other computers on a network without needing a host program or human action.

column4: What is "cryptographic salt"?
column5: A type of encryption algorithm
column6: Random data used as an additional input to a one-way function that hashes a password
column7: A key used to decrypt data
column8: A type of attack on a cryptosystem
column10: Cryptographic salt is a piece of random data used to modify a password hash. It is added to the password before hashing to prevent a common attack called a "rainbow table" attack and makes it harder to crack passwords with pre-computed tables.

column4: What is the purpose of a "Honeypot" in cybersecurity?
column5: A tool used to defend against malware
column6: A server or system designed to attract and trap hackers
column10: A honeypot is a decoy computer system or network designed to attract hackers and cyber attackers. It's a way to study their techniques, gather intelligence, and divert them away from the real network assets.

column4: What is the primary function of a "Security Information and Event Management" (SIEM) system?
column5: To manage user access permissions
column6: To collect, aggregate, and analyze security data from various sources to detect threats
column10: A SIEM system is a centralized platform that collects, aggregates, and analyzes log data and security events from across an organization's IT infrastructure. It helps security teams detect, analyze, and respond to security threats in real-time.

column4: What is a "generator expression" in Python?
column5: A function that returns a generator
column6: A list comprehension using round brackets
column7: A special kind of for loop
column8: A function that returns an iterable
column10: A generator expression is a concise way to create an iterator, similar to a list comprehension, but using round brackets `()` instead of square brackets `[]`.

column4: What is the purpose of the `__call__` method?
column5: To make an object callable like a function
column6: To call a superclass method
column7: To define a custom string representation
column8: To perform a deep copy of an object
column10: The `__call__` method allows an instance of a class to be called as a function. This makes objects callable, which can be useful for creating custom function-like objects.

column4: What is the purpose of the `__slots__` attribute in a class?
column5: To prevent the creation of new attributes in an object at runtime
column6: To define the variables of an object
column7: To improve the performance of a class by telling Python not to create a `__dict__` for each instance
column8: To specify the order of attributes in a class
column10: The `__slots__` attribute is a performance optimization used to tell Python not to use a `__dict__` to store instance attributes. This can significantly reduce the memory footprint of objects, especially when creating a large number of them.

column4: How does Python's Garbage Collector primarily work?
column5: Using a reference counting mechanism
column6: Using a mark-and-sweep algorithm
column7: Using a combination of reference counting and a cycle detector
column10: Python primarily uses a reference counting system, but to deal with reference cycles (where objects refer to each other and their reference counts never drop to zero), it also employs a separate garbage collector that finds and collects these cycles.

column4: What is the GIL (Global Interpreter Lock)?
column5: A lock on all threads that ensures only one thread executes Python bytecode at a time
column6: A lock that prevents multiple Python processes from running simultaneously
column7: A lock that is part of every Python object to ensure thread safety
column8: A mechanism to manage Python's memory allocation
column10: The GIL is a mutex that protects access to Python objects, preventing multiple threads from executing Python bytecode at the same time. This means that a single-process Python application cannot fully utilize multiple CPU cores for CPU-bound tasks.

column4: What is the time complexity of searching for an element in a binary search tree in the worst case?
column6: O(n)
column10: In the worst case, a binary search tree can degenerate into a linked list (e.g., if elements are inserted in sorted order), making the search operation linear, with a complexity of O(n).

column4: What is a self-balancing binary search tree?
column5: A tree where no node has more than one child
column6: A tree where the height difference between the left and right subtrees of any node is at most 1
column7: A tree where all leaves are at the same level
column8: A tree that automatically sorts its elements
column10: A self-balancing binary search tree (like AVL or Red-Black trees) is a type of BST that automatically keeps its height as small as possible by performing rotations, ensuring that the height difference of subtrees is maintained to ensure O(log n) search time.

column4: What is the time complexity of deleting a node from a binary search tree in the worst case?
column6: O(log n)
column10: In the worst-case scenario, a binary search tree can be unbalanced and degenerate into a linked list. In this case, finding the node to delete and its replacement can take linear time, resulting in O(n) complexity.

column4: What is the time complexity of the `dequeue` operation on a queue implemented using a circular array?
column6: O(n)
column10: A circular array-based queue can perform both enqueue and dequeue operations in constant time, O(1), by simply updating the front or rear pointers (or indices).

column4: What is the purpose of an adjacency matrix in a graph?
column5: To list all vertices and edges
column6: To store the cost of traversing an edge
column7: To represent the connections between vertices
column8: To find the shortest path between two vertices
column10: An adjacency matrix is a 2D array used to represent a graph. A value of 1 or more in `matrix[i][j]` indicates an edge between vertex "i" and vertex "j", while a 0 indicates no edge.

column4: What is the "master theorem" in algorithm analysis used for?
column5: To find the minimum spanning tree of a graph
column6: To solve recurrence relations for divide and conquer algorithms
column7: To analyze the space complexity of an algorithm
column8: To find the time complexity of a recursive algorithm without a recurrence relation
column10: The master theorem provides a cookbook method for solving recurrence relations of the form T(n) = aT(n/b) + f(n), which is common in the analysis of divide and conquer algorithms.

column4: What is the time complexity of finding an element in a balanced AVL tree?
column6: O(n)
column10: An AVL tree is a self-balancing binary search tree. Its balancing property guarantees that the height of the tree remains logarithmic, ensuring that search, insertion, and deletion operations have a time complexity of O(log n) in all cases.

column4: What is the Bellman-Ford algorithm used for?
column5: Finding the shortest path in a graph with non-negative edge weights
column6: Finding the minimum spanning tree
column7: Finding the shortest path in a graph with negative edge weights
column10: The Bellman-Ford algorithm is used to find the shortest paths from a single source vertex to all other vertices in a weighted graph, even if some of the edge weights are negative. It can also detect negative-weight cycles.

column4: What is a "Turing machine" in the context of algorithms?
column5: A physical computer
column6: A theoretical model of computation
column10: A Turing machine is a mathematical model of computation that defines an abstract machine that manipulates symbols on a strip of tape according to a table of rules. It is a theoretical foundation for what can be computed by an algorithm.

column4: Which of the following is a non-comparison based sorting algorithm?
column5: Quick Sort
column6: Merge Sort
column10: Radix Sort is a non-comparison based sorting algorithm that sorts integers by grouping them by individual digits. It can be faster than comparison-based sorts like Quick Sort or Merge Sort for certain types of data.

column4: What is the primary goal of supervised learning?
column5: To cluster similar data points
column6: To predict a target variable from labeled data
column7: To reduce the dimensionality of data
column8: To find hidden patterns in data
column10: Supervised learning uses a training dataset with labeled output to learn a mapping from inputs to the output. The goal is to predict the target variable for new, unseen data.

column4: What is a "feature" in a machine learning model?
column5: A type of algorithm
column6: An output or target variable
column7: A column in a dataset used for prediction
column10: In machine learning, a feature is an input variable that is used by the model to make predictions. It is a key piece of information in the dataset.

column4: What is overfitting?
column5: When a model is too simple to capture the underlying trend
column6: When a model performs well on the training data but poorly on unseen data
column7: When a model has a perfect score on all data
column8: When a model is too complex and slow to train
column10: Overfitting occurs when a model learns the training data and noise too well, making it perform poorly on new, unseen data. It essentially memorizes the training data instead of learning the general trend.

column4: What is a common task in unsupervised learning?
column5: Classification
column6: Regression
column10: Clustering is a classic example of an unsupervised learning task. It involves grouping similar data points together based on their features without any predefined labels.

column4: Which of these is a popular machine learning library in Python?
column5: NumPy
column6: matplotlib
column10: scikit-learn is a widely-used Python library for machine learning. It provides a vast collection of algorithms for classification, regression, clustering, and more.

column4: What is the difference between classification and regression?
column5: Classification predicts a continuous value; Regression predicts a discrete label
column6: Classification predicts a discrete label; Regression predicts a continuous value
column10: Classification models predict a discrete or categorical outcome (e.g., Spam" or "Not Spam"). Regression models predict a continuous or numerical outcome (e.g.

column4: What is a "confusion matrix" used for?
column5: To visualize model performance on unseen data
column6: To plot the training and validation loss
column7: To evaluate the performance of a classification model
column10: A confusion matrix is a table used to evaluate the performance of a classification model. It shows the number of correct and incorrect predictions for each class, including true positives, false positives, true negatives, and false negatives.

column4: What is the purpose of a validation set?
column5: To train the model on a different set of data
column6: To test the model's final performance before deployment
column7: To tune the model's hyperparameters and prevent overfitting
column10: A validation set is a portion of the training data used to tune hyperparameters and evaluate the model's performance during training, helping to prevent overfitting to the training set.

column4: What is a "hyperparameter" in machine learning?
column5: A parameter learned by the model during training
column6: An external parameter set before training starts
column10: Hyperparameters are external configuration settings for a machine learning algorithm. They are set manually before the training process begins (e.g., learning rate, number of trees in a random forest).

column4: What is the purpose of a "bias-variance tradeoff"?
column5: To find the optimal balance between model complexity and performance
column6: To prevent a model from being biased towards one class
column7: To reduce the computational cost of training
column8: To balance the training and testing data
column10: The bias-variance tradeoff describes the conflict in trying to create a model that is both simple enough to avoid overfitting (low variance) but complex enough to capture the underlying pattern (low bias). Finding the right balance is a key challenge in machine learning.

column4: What is the purpose of a kernel trick in Support Vector Machines (SVM)?
column5: To speed up the training process
column6: To find a linear decision boundary in a high-dimensional space without explicitly computing the coordinates
column7: To reduce the number of features in a dataset
column8: To handle missing values in the data
column10: The kernel trick allows an SVM to implicitly map data into a higher-dimensional feature space, enabling the algorithm to find a linear decision boundary that separates the data, even if the data is not linearly separable in the original space.

column4: Explain the difference between a bagging and boosting ensemble method.
column5: Bagging trains models sequentially; Boosting trains them in parallel
column6: Bagging reduces variance; Boosting reduces bias
column7: Bagging focuses on reducing bias; Boosting focuses on reducing variance
column8: They are different names for the same thing
column10: Bagging (like Random Forest) trains multiple models in parallel and averages their predictions to reduce variance. Boosting (like Gradient Boosting) trains models sequentially, where each new model corrects the errors of the previous one, primarily reducing bias.

column4: What is a Generative Adversarial Network (GAN)?
column5: A neural network used for regression tasks
column6: A network that combines a generative model and a discriminative model
column7: A network used for image classification
column8: A type of recurrent neural network
column10: A GAN consists of two neural networks: a generator that creates new data (e.g., images) and a discriminator that evaluates the data. They are trained in a zero-sum game, where the generator tries to fool the discriminator, and the discriminator tries to correctly identify fake data.

column4: What is the purpose of a "softmax" activation function in the output layer of a neural network?
column5: To add a non-linearity to the model
column6: To convert the outputs into probabilities that sum to 1
column7: To scale the outputs to be between -1 and 1
column8: To reduce the dimensionality of the output
column10: The softmax function is used in multi-class classification problems. It takes a vector of real numbers and normalizes them into a probability distribution, where each value is between 0 and 1 and all values sum to 1.

column4: What is a phishing attack?
column5: An attack that encrypts a user's files and demands a ransom
column6: An attack that uses malware to steal data
column7: An attack that tricks users into revealing personal information
column8: An attack that overloads a network with traffic
column10: A phishing attack is a type of social engineering where an attacker sends a fraudulent message to trick a person into revealing sensitive information, like passwords or credit card numbers.

column4: What is the purpose of a firewall?
column5: To block all internet traffic to a network
column6: To monitor and control incoming and outgoing network traffic
column8: To protect against physical theft of a computer
column10: A firewall is a network security system that monitors and controls network traffic based on a set of security rules. It acts as a barrier between a trusted internal network and untrusted external networks.

column4: What does the acronym DDoS stand for?
column5: Data Destruction on Demand System
column6: Direct Denial of Service
column10: DDoS stands for Distributed Denial of Service. It's an attack where multiple compromised computer systems flood a target's network with traffic to make the service unavailable to legitimate users.

column4: What is a "zero-day" vulnerability?
column5: A vulnerability that has been known for years
column6: A vulnerability that has a severity score of zero
column7: A newly discovered vulnerability that hackers can exploit before a patch is available
column8: A vulnerability that can only be exploited on the first day of the month
column10: A zero-day vulnerability is a software flaw that is not yet known to the vendor or the public. It can be exploited by hackers on the 'zero day' of its public discovery, before a fix is available.

column4: What is the purpose of multi-factor authentication (MFA)?
column5: To make passwords longer
column6: To protect against brute-force attacks
column7: To require more than one method of verification to grant access
column8: To automatically change a user's password
column10: MFA is a security system that requires a user to provide two or more different verification factors to gain access to a resource. It adds an extra layer of security beyond just a password.

column4: What is a SQL Injection attack?
column5: An attack that targets a database with a series of SQL queries
column6: An attack that uses malware to gain unauthorized access to a network
column7: An attack that uses malicious SQL statements to control a database server
column8: An attack that floods a database with too much traffic
column10: A SQL injection attack is a technique that uses malicious SQL statements inserted into a data input field to trick the database into executing unauthorized commands, which can lead to data theft or destruction.

column4: What is the purpose of a VPN (Virtual Private Network)?
column5: To increase network speed
column6: To allow a remote user to securely access a private network over the internet
column10: A VPN creates a secure, encrypted connection over a public network. It allows a user to send and receive data as if they were directly connected to the private network, ensuring confidentiality and security.

column4: What is a "brute-force" attack?
column5: An attack that uses a user's personal information to guess a password
column6: An attack that repeatedly tries different passwords or keys until it finds the correct one
column7: An attack that tricks a user into downloading malware
column8: An attack that targets a specific application
column10: A brute-force attack is a trial-and-error method used to guess a password or login information. The attacker systematically tries all possible combinations of characters until the correct one is found.

column4: What is the purpose of a digital certificate in network security?
column5: To encrypt network traffic
column6: To verify the identity of a website or server
column7: To store a user's password securely
column10: A digital certificate, issued by a Certificate Authority, is used to verify the identity of a website or server. It establishes a secure connection and confirms that the server is who it claims to be.

column4: What is a "Man-in-the-Middle" (MitM) attack?
column5: An attack where a hacker gains unauthorized access to a computer
column6: An attack where an attacker secretly relays and possibly alters the communication between two parties
column7: An attack that uses a trojan to steal data
column8: An attack that targets a specific piece of software
column10: In a MitM attack, an attacker places themselves between two communicating parties and intercepts their messages. The attacker can then read, modify, or inject false information into the communication without either party knowing.

column4: What is the difference between a virus and a worm?
column5: A virus self-replicates; a worm does not
column6: A virus needs a host program to spread; a worm can spread on its own
column7: A virus is a type of worm
column10: A computer virus requires a host program (like a `.exe` file) to run and spread. A worm is a standalone malicious program that can self-replicate and spread to other computers on a network without needing a host program or human action.

column4: What is "cryptographic salt"?
column5: A type of encryption algorithm
column6: Random data used as an additional input to a one-way function that hashes a password
column7: A key used to decrypt data
column8: A type of attack on a cryptosystem
column10: Cryptographic salt is a piece of random data used to modify a password hash. It is added to the password before hashing to prevent a common attack called a rainbow table" attack and makes it harder to crack passwords with pre-computed tables."

column4: What is the purpose of a "Honeypot" in cybersecurity?
column5: A tool used to defend against malware
column6: A server or system designed to attract and trap hackers
column10: A honeypot is a decoy computer system or network designed to attract hackers and cyber attackers. It's a way to study their techniques, gather intelligence, and divert them away from the real network assets.

column4: What is a "generator expression" in Python?
column5: A function that returns a generator
column6: A list comprehension using round brackets
column7: A special kind of for loop
column8: A function that returns an iterable
column10: A generator expression is a concise way to create an iterator, similar to a list comprehension, but using round brackets `()` instead of square brackets `[]`.

column4: What is the purpose of the `__call__` method?
column5: To make an object callable like a function
column6: To call a superclass method
column7: To define a custom string representation
column8: To perform a deep copy of an object
column10: The `__call__` method allows an instance of a class to be called as a function. This makes objects callable, which can be useful for creating custom function-like objects.

column4: What is the purpose of the `__slots__` attribute in a class?
column5: To prevent the creation of new attributes in an object at runtime
column6: To define the variables of an object
column7: To improve the performance of a class by telling Python not to create a `__dict__` for each instance
column8: To specify the order of attributes in a class
column10: The `__slots__` attribute is a performance optimization used to tell Python not to use a `__dict__` to store instance attributes. This can significantly reduce the memory footprint of objects, especially when creating a large number of them.

column4: How does Python's Garbage Collector primarily work?
column5: Using a reference counting mechanism
column6: Using a mark-and-sweep algorithm
column7: Using a combination of reference counting and a cycle detector
column10: Python primarily uses a reference counting system, but to deal with reference cycles (where objects refer to each other and their reference counts never drop to zero), it also employs a separate garbage collector that finds and collects these cycles.

column4: What is the GIL (Global Interpreter Lock)?
column5: A lock on all threads that ensures only one thread executes Python bytecode at a time
column6: A lock that prevents multiple Python processes from running simultaneously
column7: A lock that is part of every Python object to ensure thread safety
column8: A mechanism to manage Python's memory allocation
column10: The GIL is a mutex that protects access to Python objects, preventing multiple threads from executing Python bytecode at the same time. This means that a single-process Python application cannot fully utilize multiple CPU cores for CPU-bound tasks.

column5: A physical computer
